questions.question: According to the Hindu Marriage Act, of 1955, which of the following is considered a ground for a void marriage?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bigamy Explanation: Bigamy (entering into another marriage without dissolving the first) is classified as a void marriage, null from the time of inception. The Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 , outlines the legal framework for Hindu marriages in India, addressing the Grounds for void and voidable marriages Grounds for divorce Grounds for Void and Voidable Marriages: Void Marriage Voidable Marriage Null from the time of inception. Remains valid until annulled by the court Bigamy (entering into another marriage without dissolution of the first). Impotence (Option A ruled out) Prohibited degree of relationship (blood relations), unless permitted by custom. Unsoundness of mind of either party at the time of marriage (Option C ruled out) Sapinda relationship (relationship extending to 3rd generation in the line of ascent through the mother and 5th generation through the father) Consent obtained by force, fraud, or misconception of facts (Option D ruled out) Pregnancy of the woman by another person, unknown to the husband at the time of marriage Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 363

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered a ground for divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act, of 1955?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Financial disputes Explanation: Financial disputes are not listed as grounds for divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act of 1955. Grounds for Divorce (Hindu Marriage Act, 1955) Adultery : Voluntary sexual intercourse with any person other than his/her spouse. Cruelty : Willful and unjustifiable conduct to cause danger to life, limb, or health of another (including mental health). (Option B ruled out) Desertion : Abandonment of one spouse without reasonable cause and without consent or against the wish of the other. Apostasy : Change of religion. (Option A ruled out) Unsoundness of mind . Virulent leprosy and sexually transmitted diseases including AIDS. (Option D ruled out) Renouncing the world . Additional grounds for women : Husband convicted of rape, sodomy, or bestiality. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 363

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with her newborn baby. She explains that her husband passed away six months ago, shortly after she became pregnant. The baby was born healthy, and she is excited to introduce him to the world. What type of child is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Posthumous child Explanation: A posthumous child refers to a child born after the father has died. The baby in this scenario fits this definition perfectly. Atavism (Option A) : This term denotes the reappearance of a characteristic in an individual after several generations of absence, often due to genetic recombination. A child may resemble their grandparents rather than their parents, highlighting the complex nature of heredity. It does not relate to the status of the child's birth, so this option is incorrect. Illegitimate child (Option B) : Also known as a bastard this describes a child born out of lawful wedlock or not within a competent time after the dissolution of marriage. In this scenario, the child is born to a woman who was married, making this option incorrect. Certain conditions can render a child illegitimate, including if the alleged father is under the age of puberty, physically incapable of fathering children, not sexually accessible to the mother at the time of conception, or has blood group incompatibility. Legitimate Child : A child born during a lawful marriage or within 280 days after the marriage has been dissolved by divorce or death of the husband, as long as the mother remains unmarried. Supposititious child (Option C) : This term describes a fictitious child where a woman may pretend to be pregnant and later present a living child as her own. This can involve substituting one child for another or claiming a child after an abortion, typically for financial gain or to claim property. In this case, there is no indication of deception or substitution, so this option does not apply. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 309, 310 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 360

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman arrives at the hospital in labour. During delivery, it is noted that one of her twins is white, while the other is black whereas both the parents are of Caucasian descent. The mother recalls having had intercourse with two different partners within a short timeframe during her ovulation. What phenomenon best explains this situation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Superfecundation Explanation: Superfecundation describes the fertilization of two ova released during the same ovulation cycle, resulting from separate acts of intercourse with different partners. This can lead to fraternal twins who are half-siblings, which explains the observed differences in their appearances at birth. Superfecundation Superfetation (Option A ruled out) This refers to the fertilization of two ova released from the ovary during the same ovulation cycle , occurring through two separate acts of intercourse at short intervals. The term also describes cases where two different males father fraternal twins, known as heteropaternal superfecundation . This can result in twins who are half-siblings, exemplified by one baby being white and the other black. Medico-legal Aspect: Significant differences in the appearance of the two babies may lead to suspicions of adultery or infidelity. This occurs when two ova are fertilized at different times during the ovulation cycle , specifically involving the fertilization of a second ovum in a pregnant woman. In this case, one fetus tends to be more developed than the other. They may be born simultaneously, showing different levels of maturation, or at different times, which can range from 1 to 3 months apart. The likelihood of superfetation is higher in women with a septate or double uterus. Lithopedion (Option C) : Known as a "stone baby," this condition occurs when a fetus dies during an ectopic abdominal pregnancy and becomes calcified. It is not relevant to the situation of twin pregnancies. Fetus Papyraceus (Option D) : This term refers to a condition in twin pregnancies where one fetus may die and become flattened and mummified due to pressure from the other. It does not apply to the case described, as it does not involve two distinct fetuses from different fathers. Intraoperative photograph showing papyraceous fetus and atrophic placenta.

questions.question: A 32 y/o woman and her partner are having difficulty conceiving due to poor sperm motility. The doctor recommends artificial insemination. Which of the following methods would likely offer the highest success rate for this couple?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Intrauterine insemination (IUI) Explanation: This method involves injecting sperm directly into the uterus, which bypasses the cervix and can improve the chances of conception, particularly in cases of poor sperm motility. Artificial Insemination: Artificial insemination is a fertility treatment designed to help individuals and couples who have difficulty conceiving naturally. Sperm Count Cutoff for Fertility Treatments: IUI (Intrauterine Insemination): Recommended when the sperm count is between 5-10 million per mL . ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection): Recommended when sperm count is between 1-5 million per mL . Artificial Insemination Methods Type Method Advantages Limitations IUI (Intrauterine Insemination) (Option B) Sperm is injected into the uterus. High success, minimal pain - ICI (Intracervical Insemination) (Option A ruled out) Semen is placed in the cervix, which then travels to the uterus and fallopian tubes on its own. Low cost, suitable for various couples Lower success rate Not available option for women with thick cervical mucous. IUTPI (Intrauterine Tuboperitoneal Insemination) (Option D ruled out) Sperm injected into Fallopian tubes Bypasses infertility issues - Intratubal Insemination (Option C ruled out) In this procedure, a catheter goes through the cervix and uterus and sperm is injected only into the Fallopian tubes Effective for cervical mucus issues More invasive Reference: Artificial Insemination IUI ICSI

questions.question: A couple is considering artificial insemination with donor sperm (AID). What legal issue is most likely to arise if the procedure is performed without the husband's consent?

options.D: Increased risk of psychological issues in the child

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Legitimacy and paternity disputes Explanation: Performing artificial insemination with donor sperm (AID) without the husband’s consent could result in legal problems regarding the child’s paternity, raising questions about the child’s legitimacy and the father’s legal rights. Precautions and Legal Problems in Artificial Insemination: Precautions: Informed Consent : Informed consent is essential for medical procedures. In artificial insemination (AI), obtaining consent from both the woman and her partner (if applicable) is crucial. This should include details about the sperm source, associated risks, and legal implications. Donor Screening : Sperm donors should undergo thorough screening for genetic and infectious diseases to reduce the risk of transmitting health issues to the child and to prevent potential legal disputes over genetic defects. Confidentiality : Maintaining confidentiality is vital in AI, especially for donor insemination (AID), where the donor’s identity and the details of the procedure should be protected to avoid legal and ethical conflicts. Medico-legal Considerations in AI: Litigation Risk : Doctors may face lawsuits if a defective child is born. Screening the donor for genetic defects can help prevent this. Marriage Nullity & Divorce : AI for sterility is not grounds for divorce, but AI due to impotence is. If AID (Artificial Insemination by Donor) is done without the husband's consent, it is considered cruelty and can lead to divorce and legal action. Legitimacy : A child born via AIH (Artificial Insemination by Husband) is legitimate. But via AID is considered illegitimate and cannot inherit property. Adultery : No adultery is committed since there is no physical coitus involved. Indian law also states that women cannot be punished for adultery. Incest Risk : There is a potential risk of incest between the offspring of AI and the donor's children. Unmarried Women/Widows : Legally, there is no bar for unmarried or widowed women to undergo AID. The child would be legitimate. If a deceased husband’s sperm is used, the child is still legitimate. Genetic defects in the child (Option A): While a potential concern, this is not a primary legal issue stemming from the lack of consent. Transmission of infectious diseases (Option C): This is related to the screening process of donor sperm, not a legal issue related to consent. Increased risk of psychological issues in the child (Option D) : This could be a concern but is not a primary legal issue arising from a lack of spousal consent. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 349, 350, 351

questions.question: Which term refers to the inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in females or an incapacity to achieve orgasm?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Frigidity Explanation: Frigidity describes the inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in females, characterised by a lack of desire for sexual intercourse or the inability to achieve orgasm. Causes of Frigidity: Vaginismus- Spasmodic contraction of the vagina due to increased sensitivity in the region. It is due to a definite “cramp-like spasm” of the adductor muscles instead of a rhythmic contraction. Neurological disorders Hypothyroidism Use of sedatives or depressants Menopause Impotence (Option A) : This refers to the inability of an individual to engage in sexual intercourse and attain satisfaction, meaning they cannot copulate. Causes of Male Impotence: Psychological: Most common cause of impotence. Anxiety, depression, severe stress, fear and tension Vasculogenic: The most common organic cause Cause: Hypertension (decreased blood flow). Honeymoon Impotence: It is temporary and is caused due to anxiety. Other causes of Impotence Neurogenic Congenital Acquired causes like hydrocele. Erectile dysfunction (Option B) : This is the inability to develop and sustain an erection that is adequate for satisfactory sexual intercourse, occurring without the presence of an ejaculatory issue like premature ejaculation. It is usually a term used for males. Quod (Option C) also known as impotence quode hanc is when a male might experience impotence with one specific female but not with another. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 297- 300 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 345- 347

questions.question: What is the expected result of a Lateral Traction Test in an individual who is not accustomed to anal penetration?

options.A: Relaxation and dilation of the anal sphincter up to 4-5 cm
options.B: Reflex constriction of the anal sphincter
options.C: No response in the anal sphincter

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Reflex constriction of the anal sphincter Explanation: Individuals unaccustomed to anal penetration usually exhibit reflex constriction of the anal sphincter. Lateral Traction Test Purpose : Used to assess the anal sphincter's response, potentially indicating habitual anal penetration. Procedure : A thumb is placed on each side of the anus, and lateral traction is applied to observe sphincter reaction. Expected Results : Reflex Constriction : Typically observed in individuals who are not accustomed to anal penetration. (Option C & D ruled out) Relaxation and Dilation : In habitual anal penetration, the sphincter may relax, with the anal opening dilating up to 4–5 cm, sometimes revealing the rectum (Option A ruled out) Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 333

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the role of the Sexual Assault Forensic Examination (rape kit) concerning victim care? health needs. health needs. the victim.

options.A: The examination focuses solely on collecting evidence and does not provide medical treatment.
options.B: The examination can help victims access immediate medical care and provide resources for their
options.C: The examination requires all victims to file a police report and then provides resources for their
options.D: The examination is primarily for legal purposes and does not address the psychological well-being of

questions.explanation: resources for their health needs. Correct answer: B) The examination can help victims access immediate medical care and provide resources for their health needs. Explanation: The Sexual Assault Forensic Examination is designed not only to collect evidence but also to ensure that victims receive necessary medical treatment, addressing both physical health and immediate care needs. Sexual Assault Forensic Examination Kit (also known as a rape kit) Purpose : Preserves DNA evidence from the body, clothes, or personal items after a sexual assault and provides important medical care. No Requirement to Report : Victims can undergo an exam without reporting the crime, allowing evidence to be stored in case of later reporting. (Option C ruled out) Contents : The kit includes items like swabs, bags, documentation forms, and instructions for evidence collection (contents may vary by location). Exam Procedure : Typically includes immediate medical care, health history review, head-to-toe examination, evidence collection (e.g., DNA, blood, hair samples), and documentation of injuries. Follow-Up Care : Includes treatment for STIs, emergency contraception, and resources for further medical support. Examiners : These are conducted by trained professionals like Sexual Assault Nurse Examiners (SANEs) or Sexual Assault Forensic Examiners (SAFEs). Benefits : Helps in potential prosecution, connects DNA to databases for future investigations, and addresses physical health needs after an assault. The examination focuses solely on collecting evidence and does not provide medical treatment (Option A) : This option is incorrect. While evidence collection is a key component, the Sexual Assault Forensic Examination also includes important medical care, such as treating injuries and providing preventive measures for STIs and emergency contraception. The examination is primarily for legal purposes and does not address the psychological well-being of the victim (Option D) : Sexual Assault Forensic Examination does take into account the psychological well-being of the victim, often providing access to mental health resources and support during and after the examination. Reference: Safe Kit

questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents to a clinic with a sore throat and discomfort following a recent sexual encounter. During the examination, the clinician notes abrasions on her mouth and lips. Which sexual act is most likely associated with the injuries observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Sin of Gomorrah Explanation: Sin of Gomorrah describes oral sexual acts and could lead to abrasions in the mouth and throat, making it the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms. Unnatural sexual Acts Sodomy (Option A ruled out) Definition : Anal intercourse, historically associated with the town of Sodom. Parties Involved : This can occur between males or between a male and female. Legal Aspects : Consensual sodomy is not punishable; non-consensual acts lead to punishment for the active agent. Contexts : Common in confined environments (e.g., prisons, barracks) where individuals are isolated for long periods. Evidence : Physical examination may show signs like abrasions or relaxed anal muscles in habitual cases. Sin of Gomorrah (Buccal Coitus) (Option B) Definition : Oral sexual act involving a male organ in another’s mouth. Historical Context : Referred to as a "sin" in the town of Gomorrah. Legal Aspects : Punishable when performed without consent. Physical Evidence : Possible abrasions or teeth marks on the penis; semen in the victim's mouth may be detected up to nine hours after the act. Risks : Potential for accidental death if the penis blocks the airway. Bestiality (Option D ruled out) Definition : Sexual acts between humans and animals, typically involving smaller animals or pets. Common Animals : Includes livestock (e.g., calves, sheep) and household pets (e.g., dogs, cats). Physical Evidence : Animal hair or secretions on the person, and human sperm or injuries in the animal’s genital area. Associated Beliefs : Sometimes linked to superstitions, like the idea of curing certain diseases through intercourse with animals. Tribadism (Female Homosexuality) (Option C ruled out) Definition : Sexual activity between women for mutual gratification, also known as lesbianism. Common Acts : Includes kissing, body contact, genital apposition, and use of objects for stimulation. Historical Context : Linked to the Isle of Lesbos and sometimes called “Sapphism.” Social Dynamics : This can lead to intense emotional connections, and historically noted cases include jealousy and possessiveness among partners. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 332-334

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy exhibits extreme jealousy toward his mother’s close relationship with her new partner, showing signs of distress when she pays attention to anyone else. What psychological complex might this behaviour suggest?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Oedipus Complex Explanation: The boy's jealousy towards his mother's attention to others indicates an unconscious desire for exclusivity with her, characteristic of the Oedipus complex. Oedipus Complex Electra Complex Pharaoh Complex Refers to a son’s sexual desire for his mother. Refers to a daughter’s sexual desire for her father. (Option B ruled out) Refers to a brother’s sexual desire for his sister. (Option A ruled out) These complexes are associated with psychological issues and may be rooted in early-life trauma or unresolved conflicts. Individuals exhibiting these complexes may have psychopathic tendencies. Narcissistic Complex (Option D) : While narcissism involves self-centeredness, it does not specifically relate to the jealousy exhibited in the context of family dynamics and maternal attachment. It is usually characterized by self-love which may or may not be associated with genital excitation. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 336

questions.question: Which of the following methods of violence is most likely to directly injure the uterus and cause membrane rupture?

options.A: Inserting foreign objects like knitting needles
options.D: Injecting fluids into the uterus with a syringe

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Inserting foreign objects like knitting needles Explanation: Methods of Violence in Criminal Abortion General Violence Local Violence Abdominal Pressure : Applying force to the abdomen (kicking, kneeling, tight bandages, etc.) aiming to cause injury. Strenuous Activities: Engaging in extreme physical activities like horse riding, jumping, or falling to induce trauma. (Option B ruled out) Cupping : Using heated cups on the abdomen to create suction, possibly separating the placenta. Temperature Extremes : Alternating between hot and cold baths, aiming to shock the system. Syringing : Injecting harmful fluids (like soap or chemicals) into the uterus, risking infection and air embolism. (Option D ruled out) Syringe Aspiration : Inserting a syringe into the cervix to aspirate the gestational sac, leading to aspiration and expulsion of contents. Membrane Rupture : Using sharp objects (knitting needles, pencils) to puncture the amniotic sac, risking haemorrhage and infection. (Option A) Abortion Stick : Inserting sticks soaked in irritants (like calotropis) to cause uterine contractions. Cervical Dilation : Forcing open the cervix with objects to cause contractions. Air Insufflation : Pumping air into the uterus to detach the foetus, risking air embolism. Electric Curren t: Using electrical current on the cervix to induce contractions content expulsion. Toxic Pastes : Injecting harmful pastes into the uterus, leads to tissue damage like necrosis and infection. (Option C ruled out) Causes of Death in Criminal Abortion Immediate Delayed Vagal Inhibition Air Embolism Fat Embolism Haemorrhage Amniotic Fluid Embolism Septicaemia Generalised Peritonitis Tetanus Local infection Toxemia Pyaemia Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 314, 315 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 338, 339, 340

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is known for being an emmenagogue used in criminal abortions?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Savin Explanation: Abortifacient Drugs Description Abortifacient drugs are substances used in illegal abortions, posing severe health risks to women and potentially leading to death. Dosages and administration are often handled by unqualified individuals, increasing complications. Mechanisms of Action Ecbolics Stimulate uterine contractions to expel the fetus. Examples: Ergot, Hydrastis canadensis, quinine, lead, pituitary extract - oxytocin, synthetic estrogens. (Option A and B ruled out) Emmenagogues (Option B) Increase menstrual flow , potentially causing abortion in high doses. Examples: Savin , borax, apiol, rue. Irritants Cause reflex uterine contractions through gastrointestinal or genitourinary irritation. GIT Irritants: Strong laxatives like calomel, castor oil and saline cathartics. Genitourinary Irritants: Oils like pennyroyal, tansy and potassium permanganate, which can cause severe damage. Systemic Poisoning Induces abortion through toxic effects on the body. Examples: Lead, copper, iron, and certain organic irritants like cantharides, and unripe papaya. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 313 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 338

questions.question: Which section of the BNS involves life imprisonment for causing a miscarriage without the woman’s consent?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 89 Explanation: Criminal Abortion - Legal Aspects BNS (Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023) IPC Section (Indian Penal Code, 1860) Definition 88 (Option A ruled out) 312 Voluntary criminal abortion by anyone, including the pregnant woman, can lead to up to 3 years imprisonment and/or fine. If the woman is "quick with child" (fetal movement felt), the punishment can extend up to 7 years and a fine. 89 (Option B) 313 Causing a miscarriage without the woman’s consent is punishable by life imprisonment or up to 10 years in prison, with a fine. 90 (Option C ruled out) 314 If a miscarriage attempt leads to the woman’s death, the responsible person faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine. If done without her consent, the punishment can be life imprisonment or up to 10 years. 91 (Option D ruled out) 315 Actions to prevent a child from being born alive or causing death after birth can result in up to 10 years imprisonment, fine, or both. 92 316 Causing the death of a "quick unborn child" (after fetal movement) is considered culpable homicide, punishable by up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine. Criminal Abortion Methods Upto end of 1st month: Violent exercises Upto end of 2nd month: Abortifacient drugs 3rd or 4th month: Mechanical interference Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 312, 313 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 338 BNS to IPC

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication for pregnancy termination under the eugenic grounds of the MTP Act?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Exposure to teratogenic drugs Explanation: Indications for MTP Therapeutic (Options A and B ruled out) Pregnancy that endangers the woman's life or may cause severe physical/mental injury (e.g., cardiac disease, hypertension, epilepsy, intractable hyperemesis gravidarum, breast/ cervical cancer). Eugenic (Option C) Risk of serious physical or mental abnormalities in the fetus (e.g., exposure to teratogenic drugs, infections like rubella, structural abnormalities like anencephaly). Socio-economic Unplanned pregnancies in low socio-economic conditions or failure of contraception. Humanitarian (Option D ruled out) Pregnancy resulting from rape. Timing for MTP: Up to 12 weeks: One doctor’s opinion is required. 12 to 20 weeks: Consent of two doctors is needed. Beyond 20 weeks: Only allowed on therapeutic grounds to save the woman’s life (one doctor’s decision). Emergency cases: Any registered doctor can terminate if necessary to save the woman's life. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 312, 313 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 34, 35

questions.question: Which of the following is classified as an induced abortion performed to protect the mother's life?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Legal Abortion Explanation: Abortion Medical Definition Abortion is the expulsion of an embryo or fetus weighing 500g or less, which is not capable of surviving independently. This typically corresponds to 22 weeks of gestation. Legal Definition Abortion is the expulsion of the products of conception from the uterus at any period before full term. Types of Abortion Natural/ Spontaneous Abortion Occurs without external induction and often coincides with menstrual flow. (Option C ruled out) It is most common in the first trimester of pregnancy. Artificial/Induced Abortion: Willful termination of pregnancy before fetal viability. Legal/ Justifiable Abortion Performed to protect the life or health of the mother and follows the MTP Act. (Option B) Complications increase with gestational age, with higher rates in mid-trimester abortions. Criminal/ Illegal Abortion Induced unlawfully, often before the third month, with a high risk of complications such as infection and uterine injury. (Option A ruled out) Complications include hemorrhagic shock, septicemia, and secondary infertility. Septic Abortion (Option D): It refers to a complication of abortion involving infection of the uterus and products of conception, not an intentionally induced abortion. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 312 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 337, 341

questions.question: A woman presents with amenorrhea, breast tenderness, and morning sickness. Which category of pregnancy signs do these symptoms belong to?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Presumptive Explanation: Pregnancy Signs Presumptive Signs (Option A) Probable Signs (Option B ruled out) Positive Signs (Option C ruled out) Amenorrhea Breast Changes: Tenderness, enlargement, darkened nipples, colostrum secretion. Morning Sickness Quickening: First fetal movements felt around 16-18 weeks. Pigmentation Changes Chadwick's Sign: Bluish colour of the vaginal mucosa by the 8th week. Increased urination Fatigue Mood/Body Changes Abdominal Enlargement Hegar's Sign: Softening of the uterine isthmus (6-10 weeks). Goodell's Sign: Softened cervix by 6th week. Palmer’s Sign: Uterine contractions felt early (4-8 weeks). Piskacek's Sign: Asymmetrical uterine enlargement. Ballottement: Fetal rebound during an exam by 4-5 months. Immunological Pregnancy Tests: Detect hCG in urine/serum. Fetal Heart Sounds: Heard via stethoscope by 18-20 weeks. Fetal Movements: Palpable by 20-22 weeks. Ultrasound: Fetal visualisation from 4-5 weeks. Radiographic Imaging: Fetal skeleton visible from 16 weeks. Diagnostic (Option D): This term is not typically used in pregnancy sign classification. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 306,307 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 355, 356, 357

questions.question: Which of the following features distinguishes a fimbriated hymen from a torn hymen due to trauma?

options.D: Extension of notches to the vaginal wall

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Mucous membrane covering intact notches Explanation: Hymen Tear Fimbriated Hymen Often, it results from sexual intercourse or trauma. It can be associated with injuries to surrounding areas, such as the perineum and labia. Usually occurs at the lateral edges of the labia and extends into the vaginal wall. Traumatic tears may not have mucous membrane covering and can be located posteriorly. (Option B ruled out) Characterised by a wavy or irregular border with symmetrical notches. (Option A ruled out) Notches are typically found anteriorly and do not penetrate the vaginal wall. (Option D ruled out) The mucous membrane remains intact around natural notches. It requires careful examination to differentiate it from traumatic tears. Hymen: The hymen is a thin mucous membrane at the vaginal opening, which changes in size during childhood and puberty. Hymen Rupture Causes: Most commonly occurs due to sexual intercourse. Other causes include: Accidental injuries (e.g., falls). Masturbation with large objects. Medical examinations and procedures. Insertion of foreign objects. Infections (e.g., diphtheria, fungal infections). Poor hygiene leads to scratching. Use of sanitary tampons. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 363

questions.question: A medical student is studying the anatomical variations of the hymen. Which of the following statements regarding hymen types and their implications is true?

options.A: A single central opening characterises a septate hymen.
options.B: The cribriform hymen features multiple small openings in the membrane.
options.C: An infantile hymen typically has multiple small openings.
options.D: The annular hymen typically have two side-by-side openings.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The cribriform hymen features multiple small openings in the membrane. Hymen Types: The hymen, a mucous membrane fold at the vaginal opening, can have several types: Type Description Annular Centrally located opening (Option D ruled out) Semilunar Anteriorly located opening Infantile Small, linear central opening (Option C ruled out) Septate Two side-by-side openings (Option A ruled out) Cribriform Multiple openings (Option B) Vertical Vertical orientation of the opening Imperforate No opening present Causes of Hymen Rupture: Cause Description Sexual Intercourse The most common cause of hymen rupture. Masturbation The use of large objects can cause a rupture. Accidents Falls onto sharp objects may lead to a rupture. Medical Procedures Gynaecological exams or surgeries can cause a rupture. Foreign Body Insertion Possible in cases of abuse or forced sexual activity Use of Sanitary Tampons Tampon usage may contribute to hymen rupture.

questions.question: A 24 y/o woman is anxious about societal perceptions of her virginity after her first sexual experience. Which of the following statements is true regarding virginity and defloration?

options.A: Virginity can be medically assessed by examining the hymen.
options.B: Defloration is solely marked by the hymen's rupture during first intercourse.
options.C: Virginity is a social construct that varies across cultures.
options.D: False virgins always present with small and firm breasts.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Virginity is a social construct that varies across cultures. Explanation: Virginity is primarily a social construct influenced by cultural values, rather than a medical concept with objective criteria. While misconceptions about the hymen persist, the notion of virginity varies significantly across cultures. Definitions: Virginity : A social, cultural, and religious construct. (Option C) Refers to the state of never having engaged in sexual intercourse. Lacks a medical or scientific definition, highlighting its subjective nature across different societies. Defloration : Refers specifically to the rupture of the hymen during the first vaginal intercourse. It is increasingly recognized that hymen condition does not reliably indicate sexual activity. (Option B ruled out) Hymen and Virginity: Intact hymens are inaccurately linked to virginity. Factors other than intercourse can rupture the hymen, including- accidents, medical exams or insertion of objects into the vagina. Hymen's appearance varies. It is usually thin. It could also be tough, fleshy and cartilaginous. Variability and potential for healed injuries make hymen examination an unreliable indicator of sexual history. (Option A ruled out) Category True Virgin False Virgin Genital Signs Intact, rigid, inelastic hymen; admits only a fingertip, causing pain. Thick, fleshy labia majora that close the vaginal orifice; small, pink labia minora covered by labia majora. Narrow vagina with prominent rugae; full finger cannot be admitted. Present fossa navicularis, intact fourchette, narrow vestibule, small clitoris, intact posterior commissure. Intact hymen that may be loose, elastic, or thick; admits two fingers easily. Less fleshy labia majora; vaginal orifice may be visible; enlarged, pigmented labia minora. Roomy vagina with less prominent rugae; full finger can be admitted. Disappearance of fossa navicularis; torn and healed fourchette; wider vestibule; enlarged clitoris; possibly torn posterior commissure. (Option D ruled out) Extra-Genital Signs Small, hemispherical, firm breasts; pink areola. Larger, pendulous, flabby breasts; pigmented areola. Reference: Hymen Hymen & Virginity Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 353, 354, 355 Knight’s Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition, Page 431

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) guidelines on surrogacy?

options.A: The surrogate mother must be under 45 years of age.
options.B: The ART clinic is allowed to advertise for surrogate mothers.
options.C: Surrogacy should only be considered for those physically or medically unable to carry a child.
options.D: A woman can be a surrogate mother up to three times in her lifetime.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The ART clinic is allowed to advertise for surrogate mothers. Explanation: ICMR guidelines prohibit ART clinics from advertising for surrogate mothers or engaging in commercial dealings for surrogacy. The couple is responsible for finding the surrogate. Surrogate Mother: A surrogate mother is a woman who carries a child for another couple or individual, intending to give up the baby after birth. Surrogacy can be: Traditional surrogacy : The surrogate is the biological mother. Gestational surrogacy : The surrogate carries an embryo that is not biologically hers, typically through in vitro fertilisation (IVF). Commercial Surrogacy: Previously common in India, commercial surrogacy involved contractual agreements with financial compensation for surrogates beyond medical and pregnancy costs but is now prohibited under the 2018 Surrogacy (Regulation) Bill. Altruistic Surrogacy: Supported by the 2018 bill, altruistic surrogacy allows surrogates to receive coverage only for medical and pregnancy-related expenses, emphasizing a non-monetary, ethical approach without profit. ICMR Guidelines on Surrogacy: Surrogates can be known, unknown, or a relative of the couple. If a relative, she should be from the same generation as the intended mother. Considered only for those who are physically or medically unable to carry a pregnancy to term. (Option C ruled out) Genetic parents must legally adopt the child born via surrogacy. Payment to the surrogate mother must cover all pregnancy-related expenses, documented in an agreement. ART clinics cannot advertise for surrogate mothers or engage in commercial surrogacy; the couple is responsible for finding a surrogate. (Option B) The surrogate mother must be under 45 years of age. (Option A ruled out) A woman can be a surrogate no more than three times in her lifetime. (Option D ruled out) Clinics must guide couples through surrogacy, ensuring surrogates meet health criteria for full-term pregnancy. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 351, 352 Surrogacy
